prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA - My boyfriend was lying down while I was unclogging the toilet
AITA

Hello people! I usually lurk here, but this Saturday something happened and I really need to know who is right in this situation, as my boyfriend (together 4 years, living together) claims he did nothing wrong and that I’m TA while I think the complete opposite.


So, our toilet clogged, after he had some mild stomach problems. At first, it wasn’t too bad, but by Friday night it wasn’t flushing at all. I tried to unclog it and nothing worked.

The next day, we went to buy another sort of tool (an auger) and while buying it, he seemed already quite annoyed, but got a bit better after some hours. We got home, he tried for one hour to unclog it (while I hovered around and tried to help, by watching videos and trying myself a bit), then I tried for 2 more hours while he urged me to give up.

I have to point out that it’s a 40 m2 apartment, no walls other than toilet, so our bed was literally next to the problem, and we don’t have another bathroom. 

I was very tired of not having a toilet working and also a pool of shit next to me, so I asked him if I could call my dad so he could help us. He said ok, but that he wouldn’t help if things went wrong (red flag n1).

My dad arrived and my BF was laying down. My dad greeted him and he kept laying down. My dad started working on the clog and he was laying down.

After 3 hours of work (I was actively helping and cleaning the whole time), it was finally over and the clog was gone (we had to remove it to access the problem, and it was all QUITE disgusting), and my dad took a shower and asked for a pair of shorts, as his were dirty of shit... that didn’t go very well with BF, because “he came unprepared”,  but relented.

My dad went home very angry at my boyfriend, as he literally didn’t do anything, and so were I.

My BF’s reasoning: I should be grateful that he let my dad fix the toilet. That it wasn’t such a big deal or urgent at all. That the best he could do was to do nothing, because he disagreed with the way my dad was fixing it.

I’m completely baffled. To me, when someone does you a favor (as fixing a toilet full of shit), you should be grateful. But apparently I don’t have real world standards according to him. My dad doesn’t want to speak to him anymore, and I can’t blame him actually.

So, Reddit, AITA?
(Btw, I’m not only looking for validation, because I’d like to know what makes one think like he does and if I’m actually so delusional to expect common curtesy from my BF). 
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the author (the person who wrote the AITA post) is in the wrong. The situation involves a toilet clog that the boyfriend didn't help fix properly, even when the author's dad had to come over. The boyfriend was laid back, didn't assist, and seemed ungrateful afterward.

First, I need to understand the key points. The toilet clogged, the author tried to fix it, then bought a tool with the boyfriend. The boyfriend tried for an hour, then stopped and told the author to give up. They called the author's dad, who fixed it in three hours while the boyfriend just lay down. The dad got angry because the boyfriend didn't help and now refuses to talk to him. The boyfriend claims it wasn't urgent and he didn't want to help the way the dad was doing it.

The author feels wronged, thinking the boyfriend should have been grateful. The boyfriend doesn't see it that way. The user thinks the author isn't wrong but wants confirmation.

So, considering social norms, when someone helps you with a big problem (like fixing a clogged toilet), especially in a stressful situation, it's customary to show gratitude and offer help. The boyfriend's behavior—laying down, not assisting, being ungrateful—seems rude. The author's expectations are reasonable. The boyfriend's excuse about disagreeing with the method doesn't justify his inaction. The dad's anger is understandable given the situation. Therefore, the author isn't in the wrong. The answer should be B.
